newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Runoff mayoral vote seen in Brazil's two top cities.
newsitem.headline: Runoff mayoral vote seen in Brazil's two top cities.

text.p: Voters in Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro will face a runoff election for mayor in November after no candidate won more than 50 percent of votes in Thursday's municipal election.
In Sao Paulo, Brazil's largest city, right-wing candidate Celso Pitta just missed winning outright in the first round after receiving 49 percent of the vote.

Pitta, a political neophyte who had never before run for political office, could become Sao Paulo's first black mayor if he beats runner-up Luiza Erundina of the Worker's Party (PT) in the Nov. 15 runoff.
In Rio de Janeiro, Pedro Conde of the Liberal Front Party (PFL) will face Sergio Cabral of President Fernando Henrique Cardoso's Social Democrat Party (PSDB).
Voting nationwide came off smoothy as more than 100 million Brazilians went to the polls on Thursday to pick mayors and councilmen in 5,500 municipalities across the country.

Local issues such as public transport, crime and housing dominated voter concerns, disappointing some opposition candidates who hoped to turn the nationwide poll into a referendum on Cardoso's free market reforms.
Analysts said Cardoso, who is halfway through a four-year term in office, would appear to have emerged strengthened by Thursday's election results.
They said the president would benefit from signs that voters were choosing candidates with moderate platforms and rewarding predictable politicians that offered them continuity.
"This election was all about continuity and that is good news for the president," said political analyst Walder de Goes.
With the elections now over, Cardoso is expected to concentrate his efforts on persuading congressmen to approve a constitutional amendment that will allow him to run for re-election.
Billed as Latin America's first computerised election, some 30 percent of voters punched candidates' numbers into shoe-box sized electronic ballot boxes.
However electoral officials confessed being embarassed by delays in vote counting process which continued long after it was scheduled to end.
